questions.question_text:
A workstation has RAID 1 and RAID 5 arrays. Although performance is not degraded, management software is reporting a hard disk failure.
Which of the following should a technician do NEXT?

choices.A: Check one of the RAID 1 disks for failure
choices.C: Check one of the RAID 5 disks for failure
choices.B: Rebuild the RAID 1 disks for failure

comments.content: I think the same too, plus checking raid one first would be more logical because data would be lost if the other hard drive of RAID 1 would also fail.

discussion.content: Citing no degradation is misleading. If you have a RAID 5 and one drive fails, you WILL have degraded performance. Same for RAID 6. I have experienced this many times. Slow as molasses while disk remains failed and during the re-build. If you have a RAID 1 disk fail, you likely will not note any degradation as the disks are mirrored. I would go with checking RAID 1 first, but CompTIA likes to make the practical, impractical.

comments.content: RAID 5 because that would have be composed of three as opposed to RAID 1 which only has two and would fail if one of them stopped working.
RAID 1 is mirroring not stripping. 1 disk failure is not a problem.

discussion.content: it should be RADI 1?

Which is faster RAID 1 or 5?
Raid 1 has a relatively slow write speed, slower than using a single disk. RAID 5 has a write speed much faster than a single disk, but lags slightly due to the need for creating parity data.Apr 8, 2021

RAID 5 Degrades in performance when a disk is lost
RAID 1 Mirrored you won't notice a performance decrease when a disk is lost.

RAID 0 = Striped volume (min 2 drives) (NOT fault tolerant)(High capacity)(speed)
RAID 1 = Mirrored (min 2 drives) (fault tolerant)(relatively expensive) 
RAID 5 = Striped with parity volume (min 3 drives) (has fault tolerance)(good reading)
RAID 6 = Striping with double parity (min 4 drives) (has fault tolerance)(good reading)(slow to rebuild)
RAID 10 = RAID 1 + RAID 0 (min 4 drives)(nested)(A striped set from a series of mirrored drives)

Selected Answer: A
It has to be RAID1. Mirroring by definition allows one drive to fail but the RAID will continue to operate at the same speed, or no performance hike. However the bad drive will still be recognized and identified by the RAID controller.

Selected Answer: A
The answer is RAID 1 needs to be checked. If RAID 5 was dying, it would have performance drgradation. No degradation = not RAID 5... it has to be RAID 1 that needs to be checked.

RAID 1 is working since its using redundancy to access things from both RAID 5s on both arrays. However, hard disk failure lliterally means one of the Hard drives have failed. Since Raid 1 is working fine =, than you have to check the RAID 5 drives.

comments.content: So the answer is A. Thank again Bobo55 for sharing your experience :D
did you get that answer right on the test with a?

discussion.content:
I believe the answer is RAID-1. When RAID-1 suffer a failed disk it doesn't lose much performance since it just duplicating the same data on another drive (in fact the performance would improve). 

If RAID-5 suffer a failed disk, it would be extremely slow, because each disk sector must be recovered by reading information from the good drives and performing a mathematical reconstruction.

You can read more here (do control f "consequence of raid-5 degradation): redsharknews.com/technology-computing/item/877-raid-everything-you-need-to-know

questions.question_text:
A company wants to purchase new equipment for its help desk team. Team members work in a 24/7 environment and share desks with coworkers from other shifts. The company already has dual monitors set up on each desk but decides replacing the existing desktops with laptops would be the best business decision to support the mobility needs.
Which of the following laptop features or accessories would be BEST suited for this business environment?

choices.C: Do a full backup of the system data
choices.D: Perform a format and System Restore
choices.B: Document the findings and report them to the user

discussion.content:
I believe the C is correct because backing up data is part of the "identify the problem" procedure. 

I've to admit it is a bit strange at first but should always backup your data even if it may include the malware. That way you always have a backup of your machine and your data. Now the key method is to not restore the entire backup to your machine. Only go for the specific files and pieces of data you know aren't infected from that backup. 

You can learn more here: https://askleo.com/should-i-backup-if-my-machine-is-infected/
“Following best practice methodologies”- CompTIA A+ troubleshooting six steps. C is the correct answer.
I think it's A. If you suspect of an infection, you should not backup.

comments.content: WRONG, it says full backup of system "DATA" and not the entire system.

The user reports only new software installations have been made to the laptop.
Following best practice methodologies, which of the following should the technician perform NEXT to resolve the problem?

A user is given a new tablet. When using the touch screen, the user reports the cursor highlights and selects items unintentionally. The issue does not happen when using an external mouse.
Which of the following should the technician do FIRST to resolve this issue?

discussion.content:
No... calibrate the touch screen first. It's easier and quicker than updating the driver. That should be the first step. If that doesn't work, THEN update the touch screen driver...
